sub_topic: Solving non-homogeneous systems of linear equations
message_1:
Consider the non-homogeneous system of linear equations: 

\begin{align*}
  x + 2y - 3z &= 6\\
  2x - 3y + 4z &= 1\\
  x + y - z &= -4\\
\end{align*}

Solve the system of equations using the method of your choice.
message_2:
We will solve this system of linear equations using the Gaussian elimination method.

First, we write the augmented matrix for the given system of equations:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 2 & -3 & 6 \\
2 & -3 & 4 & 1 \\
1 & 1 & -1 & -4
\end{array}\right]
$$

Now, we perform row operations to get the matrix in row-echelon form.

Step 1: Subtract the first row from the third row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 2 & -3 & 6 \\
2 & -3 & 4 & 1 \\
0 & -1 & 2 & -10
\end{array}\right]
$$

Step 2: Add twice the first row to the second row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 2 & -3 & 6 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & -11 \\
0 & -1 & 2 & -10
\end{array}\right]
$$

Step 3: Add the second row to the third row:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 2 & -3 & 6 \\
0 & 1 & -2 & -11 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -21
\end{array}\right]
$$

The matrix is now in row-echelon form. Notice that the last row represents the equation $0x + 0y + 0z = -21$, which is a contradiction. This means that the given system of linear equations has no solution, and it is an inconsistent system.
